title.narrative: SSCJR - Joint Humanitarian Response for South Sudan COVID-19 Joint Response

description.narrative: Cordaid will implement directly and through 2 local partners. In Juba Cordaid is working with the South Sudan Youth Fight against C-19, reaching young people in particular who make up 70% of the population with C-19 awareness and soap. Technical support, FSL and water are provided by Cordaid, complementing the activities of StC, ICCO and HaC. In Rubkona health services are provided by Children Aid South Sudan with technical support from Cordaid, and FSL and WASH is provided by Cordaid. Trained health promotors are selected among the community, enabling the advancement of awareness and enhanced knowledge among local communities. Cash is used but only for food and start up grants for women as it gives people choice and dignity, is more flexible and stimulates local markets. Cordaid has an experienced drilling team and all equipment in place to ensure smooth drilling and rehabilitation of wells. Its C-19 guidelines will ensure quality services and protection for staff and beneficiaries

As C-19 has worsened the already precarious situation of many South Sudanese the main objective of the intervention is to reduce the impact of C-19 on 66,000vulnerable people by addressing their immediate Health, WASH and FSL needs in severely affected areas Juba and Rubkona. Protection is mainstreamed and special C-19 measures are taken to protect staff and beneficiaries: Health: To improve case detection and treatment, benefiting 12,000 people, 4 triage centres are established for screening, identification, and detection of suspected C-19 cases. Frontline workers are adequately equipped and trained in C-19 case detection and management/treatment following MoH C-19 guidelines and centres will be provided with supplies and equipment for effective management of suspected/confirmed cases. HF will be provided with IPC WASH support for which Cordaid has developed specific guidelines. RRT will be enabled to conduct investigations and referrals and Bentiu hospital laboratory will be enabled to scale up testing by training and provision of testing materials and staff WASH: To address lack of information, water and hygiene items, C-19 awareness sessions with provision of IEC materials and hygiene items will be provided to 60,000 people. 3 boreholes will be installed in areas consulted with village elders and women and 5 repaired and WMC established. In schools, churches handwashing facilities with rainwater harvesting are installed and IEC materials and soap are provided. In central village locations, tippy taps are installed and provided with information and soap. FSL: To meet immediate food needs of 2,208 most vulnerable, already identified women children and elderly persons cash for food (MEB: EUR85/HH for 3 months) is provided. They also receive seeds, tools and training to address their longer term food needs. With women bearing the brunt of the pandemic, FSL activities will focus on women. 50 women are trained in business skills and rewarded with a start-up grant

mailing-address.narrative: Grote Marktstraat 45, Den Haag, Zuid Holland, 2511 BH

title.narrative: Saving Lives Thematic Indicators
Number of people provided with water and sanitation services

description.narrative: No. of people who have received (access to) water and sanitation services

title.narrative: Number of people provided with food items
Strengthened Health Systems and Access to Resilient Health Services
Number of people trained to provide COVID-19 Awareness Raising & Prevention activities
Access to Life saving basic services provided
Number of people trained to provide COVID-19 Awareness Raising & Prevention activities
Number of people provided with water in response to COVID-19
Number of people provided with sanitation services in response to COVID-19
Number of people enabled to meet their basic food needs in response to COVID-19
People's Resilience to Future Outbreaks Strengthened & Sustained Food Security & Livelihood of vulnerable people
Number of people trained to provide COVID-19 Awareness Raising & Prevention activities
Strengthened responsiveness and accountability of security, justice and Civic Space
Number of people trained to provide COVID-19 Awareness Raising & Prevention activities
Short-term livelihood support
FSC-I1: Number of people provided with resources to protect and start rebuilding livelihoods assets

description.narrative: Resources that enable people to protect and rebuild their livelihood assets include seeds, livestock, tools, business grant, etc. Any kind of transfer modality (in-kind, voucher, restricted cash) and combination thereof to support, protect and enable the restoration/protection/access of/to livelihood assets.

title.narrative: Availability of, access to and consumption of food
FSC-I2: Number of people enabled to meet their basic food needs (non-cash)

description.narrative: Basic food needs: assistance, combined with beneficiaries' own resources, to international standard of 2100 kcal per person per day for the period of the action. Any kind of transfer modality (in-kind, voucher, cash) and combination thereof with objective to ensure immediate access to the necessary food commodities. This may include supplementary foods provided alongside general distribution for vulnerable people.

title.narrative: Hygiene promotion
WSH-I1: Number of people having regular access to soap to meet hygienic needs

description.narrative: Regular and timely access: 250g soap/p/m for personal hygiene, 200g soap/p/month for laundry. This includes hygiene/dignity kits. Access may be in-kind or though voucher distribution or through unconditional restricted cash to enable beneficiary to buy soap (without compromising access to other basic needs). Distributed items need to be culturally acceptable i.e. take into account local practice and expectations.

title.narrative: Water Supply
WSH-I4: Number of people having access to sufficient and safe water for domestic use

description.narrative: Access: maximum distance to water point 500m, queuing time less than 15min, filling time maximum 3 min/20 litres or as locally agreed. Water access should be during the whole period of implementation unless action is mostly related to building the local water delivery capacity. Sufficient: covering basic needs, i.e. 7.5-15 l/p/d or as locally agreed. Safe: 1) low risk of faecal contamination, 2) No faecal coliforms detectable in any 100-ml sample, 3) For piped water supplies, or for all water supplies at times of risk or presence of diarrhoea epidemic, water is treated with a disinfectant to achieve free chlorine residual at the tap of 0.5 mg per litre and turbidity is below 5 NTU, 4) If for a short period, water which is contaminated chemically or radiologically is used, no (significant probability of) negative health effect is (likely to be) detected. Domestic use: drinking, cooking and personal hygiene (incl. laundry)

title.narrative: Hygiene promotion (Awareness)
WSH-I6: Number of people reached with hygiene promotion/awareness raising activities

description.narrative: Hygiene promotion/awareness raising activities. Could be training, campaigns, radio broadcasts, flyers etc. Excludes the distribution of Hygiene/dignity kits that should be covered under WHS-I1.

title.narrative: Health infrastructure rehabilitation
HEA-I1: Number of health facilities rehabilitated

description.narrative: Health facility rehabilitated: - physical conditions of the facility prevents/limits the spread of nosocomial infections - the facility is safe (e.g. against natural hazards) - WASH services available respecting standards - storage conditions for medical supplies are according to norms. - Medical waste is disposed of according to standards. Use this sub-sector and indicator only if the project contributed substantially to the rehabilitation.

title.narrative: Epidemics
HEA-I4: Number of outbreak alerts responded to

description.narrative: Number of alerts for which an investigation and/or control measures were implemented.

title.narrative: Primary Health
HEA-I5: Number of primary health care consultations

description.narrative: Number of curative consultations provided either through existing facilities which received substantial support through the project or through parallel, self-standing emergency facilities.

title.narrative: Localisation
LOC-I1: % of budget that went to national and local actors
Accountability
ACC-I1: Number of crisis-affected people who are also involved in the design, implementation, monitoring and/or evaluation of the programme

description.narrative: Participation is defined as the involvement of crisis-affected people in one or more phases of the programme: assessment, design, implementation, monitoring or evaluation. Participation does not take place when activities are carried out in exchange for a salary of 'in-kind' payment unless the affected people are involved in decision-making processes and have an impact on decisions that affect them. Please describe in the actvity description what this involvement specifically entails and in which phase of the program conflict-affected people are involved.

title.narrative: Capacity Building (localisation)
LOC-I2: % of budget spent on capacity building of national an local actors

description.narrative: This concerns capacity building such as training and on the job support to national and local actors. This is captured under "Capacity building local partners" in the DRA budget. Note that this does not include local offices of INGOs.

title.narrative: Capacity Building (reach)
LOC-I3: Number of national and local actors supported with capacity-building

description.narrative: Total number of national and local actors that received capacity-building support during implementation. In case more than one individual from a national/local actor participate in the capacity building activities. Note that this does not include local offices of INGOs.

title.narrative: Adaptations to JR
ACC-I2: Number of adaptations in the design and/or implementation of the JR, as a result of the input from beneficiaries.

description.narrative: Active participation of beneficiaries could lead to concrete proposals in programme design and/or on how to improve existing implementation. In the activity description/comment field, indicate how this input from beneficiaries is gathered (planned) and at mid/end-term stage, what input was received from beneficiaries and to which adaptations this has led.

title.narrative: Prevention and response to COVID-19 pandemic related to WASH
WSH-COV-I7: Number of people receiving COVID-19 related assistance (WASH)
Prevention and response to COVID-19 pandemic related to Health
HEA-COV-I9: Number of people receiving COVID-19 related assistance (Health)
Prevention and response to COVID-19 pandemic related to Food Security & Livelihoods
FSC-COV-I3: Number of people receiving COVID-19 related assistance (FS&L)
Saving Lives Corporate Indicators
Number of beneficiaries reached (SL)

description.narrative: Number of people who benefitted directly or indirectly with life-saving humanitarian assistance and/or resilient recovery services and/or disaster preparedness from activities in a humanitarian response implemented by Cordaid and implementing partners

title.narrative: Health Corporate Indicators
Number of outpatient consultations

description.narrative: Number of outpatient consultations conducted by a healthcare practioner at a health facility supported by a Cordaid Health Programme
